Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Policy and Engineering Design for Complex Systems with Applications to Distribution Systems within Smart Electric Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to create a framework for integrated policy and engineering design considering multiple goals of policy makers, stakeholders, and dynamic stability. The research objective will be achieved by establishing domain-independent multilevel design techniques through the integration of mathematical programs with equilibrium constraints, constructs from multi-objective optimization, games with vector payoffs, and stability theories. The framework will be validated through the design of market-oriented feed-in-tariff policies for smart electric grids, accounting for economic, environmental, technical, and energy-security objectives. Domain-specific models will be developed using techniques such as continuation power flow analysis and volatility analysis. The research will result in a general framework that can be applied to other complex systems that require the integrated consideration of technical design and policy decisions. Deliverables include a computational framework for integrated policy and engineering design, extension of existing mathematical constructs to multi-objective problems, and specific insights into the design of feed-in-tariff policies.

If successful, the results of this research will enable computational policy design using multilevel design techniques. The applications include large-scale complex systems such as energy, transportation and telecommunication infrastructure. The results will be disseminated through industrial partners, university's extension energy program, journal publications and conference presentations. The outreach efforts are designed to increase public awareness through local science centers, to support local communities through design-oriented service-learning projects, and to increase the participation of women and minorities through undergraduate research. Project outcomes will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses. High school students will be engaged through existing design competitions to educate them about engineering, energy, and policy-related issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has resulted in a mathematical framework to help engineering systems designers and policy makers in designing and operating complex engineered systems. The unique characteristics of the framework include simultaneous consideration of physical behaviors of systems and the socio-economic aspects which are typically addressed independently by different stakeholders. It enhances our understanding about how entities interact in large-scale complex systems, and builds better strategies and protocols to improve the reliability, resilience, security, and social welfare. While the mathematical framework is developed in the context of electric grids, it is domain independent, and can be extended to other complex systems including transportation systems, telecommunication systems, water distribution systems, and clusters of interconnected buildings.

The framework enables longer-term system planning decisions through a bi-level model that integrates decisions made by policy makers and generators. The model enables computational exploration of the impacts of different policies, such as feed-in-tariff policies for renewable energy generation. The model also helps in designing new policies considering physical constraints in power grids. A specific example is the development of a quasi feed-in-tariff policy with time-varying subsidy prices, where the subsidy varies based on hourly variations in demand. The designed quasi feed-in-tariff policy is predicted to outperform fixed subsidy prices in terms of equilibrium generation quantities and optimal subsidy prices.

The framework also provides a novel solution to the multi-time-scale challenge in complex power systems. The operation of complex systems in general, and power system in particular, entails solving problems with significantly different time-scales ranging from a time horizon of years to daily/hourly economic dispatch problems, to milliseconds for regulating voltages of generators. The sheer differences in the time-scales of the aforementioned classes of problems make it difficult to simultaneously analyze the overall operation of energy systems for all time-scales. Specifically, decisions made at different time-horizons can significantly affect other decisions made for different time-horizons, a major challenge in the design of complex engineering systems.

The mathematical framework developed in this project integrates computational methods that address this time-scale challenge. Specifically, decisions made by power system stakeholders are modeled for two different time-scales: the hourly/daily and the millisecond operation levels. The hourly operation level corresponds to solving energy dispatch problems to determine which generators should produce how much instantaneous electric power. The millisecond operation problem corresponds to keeping large electric-power generators safe and secure. The developed methods solve the two problems simultaneously in a computationally-efficient routine, which is necessary to avoid disruptions or potential blackouts. This has the potential to assist system operators in making stability-aware operational decisions that are cost-effective and computationally tractable, while guaranteeing that the system is operating within the desired steady-state and transient performance levels.

The framework also enables design of risk mitigation strategies against cyber-attacks in complex systems. Risk mitigation is defined as taking steps to reduce adverse effects resulting from potential cyber-attacks. We showed that current methods that protect complex power systems are intolerant to cyber-attacks, and that a clever attacker can do significant damage by maliciously attacking measurements coming from generators and electric substations in some critical locations. Then, we presented a monitoring algorithm that quantifies the effect of potential attacks, generates real-time dynamic alarms to power system operators, and identifies and isolates the components being attacked such that the influence of attacks does not propagate to other elements of power systems. These techniques enable complex system operators to make better real-time decisions such as identifying faulty components and isolating erroneous measurement units. These methods are extensible to other complex engineering systems such as water distribution networks.

Finally, a system stability index for voltage has been developed and integrated with the multi-objective design problem. The developed voltage stability indices (VSI) have been compared with voltage stability margins computed using the full nonlinear analysis of three-phase continuation power flow. The developed VSI based on graph theoretical approach and three-phase current injection approach can handle unbalanced three phase system with multiple distributed energy resources. Three-phase distribution locational marginal price tool was developed to compute dynamic price and to compute associated price stability indices for power distribution system markets.

Broader impacts: The project has supported the training and education of five graduate students. One of the PhD students supported by this project has joined as a tenure track faculty member within the US, and will be continuing research activities in related areas. Other students have taken up various positions within industry. The results from this project have been disseminated through journal and conference publications. The results have been presented to public utility companies, and diverse research communities including systems engineering, energy policy, power and energy society, design engineering, dynamic systems and control, engineering optimization.
